Unfortunately, the moon isn’t made out of cheese. It does, however, consists of more complicated elements, like the ones found here on Earth.

The moon does not move in a perfect circle; it has a distinct elliptical orbit. When the moon is at its farthest approach from the Earth, or at apogee, it’s about 252,088 miles away. At its closest approach, or at perigee, the moon 238,855 miles away. According to NASA, that’s a distance of almost 32 and 28 Earths respectively!

It is a common misconception that the Earth’s shadow causes the moon phases (when that happens, it is called a lunar eclipse). Lunar phases are actually caused by the light from the sun and the moon’s orbit around the Earth. The sun always illuminates half of the moon, but we see it at different angles as it rotates around the Earth. We only see the part that the sun is illuminating."

The moon makes a complete orbit around the Earth approximately once every 27.3 days. Similarly, It also takes approximately 27 days for the moon to rotate once on its axis. However, the most interesting detail of them all is that the moon is moving away from the earth at approximately 1.6 inches per year. This means, in 600 million years or so, there won’t be any more total solar eclipses!

Though it may seem like the Earth moves up and then down (depending on your perspective), the moon rises in the east and sets in the west, like the sun and other planets. This is because of the rotation of the Earth, which happens to be turning in a clockwise direction.

During a supermoon, the moon is a little closer and brighter than usual. This is because the moon moves in an elliptical orbit.
There are three types of lunar eclipses: total, partial and penumbral. The most dramatic and perhaps prominent one of them all is the total lunar eclipse.

A lunar eclipse occurs when the moon passes directly behind Earth and into its shadow. During this time, sunlight no longer reflects off the moon, and it causes the moon to appear more dark than usual.

A supermoon requires two things to occur: The moon needs to be at its closest approach to the Earth in its approximate 27.3 day orbit, and the moon also needs to be at its full phase, which happens every 29.5 days.
